guide.conclusion: This project first appeared in CRAFT VOLUME 09, pages 40-45.

flags.title: From CRAFT
flags.text: This project first appeared on the pages of CRAFT or on Craftzine.

guide.introduction:
The eco-savvy shopper brings her own reusable bags to the store, at least when she remembers them. But when life hands you lemons (or wasteful plastic bags), make lemonade — or in this case — toadstools!

The Toadstool Tote and coordinating Rain Bucket Hat are made entirely from plastic shopping bags. When layered and heated with an iron, plastic bags fuse together to create a durable material similar in feel to Tyvek. Fused plastic can be easily cut and sewn into a variety of projects, such as the 2 demonstrated here.
guide.introduction_rendered:
The eco-savvy shopper brings her own reusable bags to the store, at least when she remembers them. But when life hands you lemons (or wasteful plastic bags), make lemonade — or in this case — toadstools!

The Toadstool Tote and coordinating Rain Bucket Hat are made entirely from plastic shopping bags. When layered and heated with an iron, plastic bags fuse together to create a durable material similar in feel to Tyvek. Fused plastic can be easily cut and sewn into a variety of projects, such as the 2 demonstrated here.

Relevant parts
  • Plastic shopping bags
  • Parchment paper
  • Ribbon
  • Glue
  • Templates
Tools
  • Iron
  • Ironing board
  • Pencil
  • Ruler
  • Scissors
  • Sewing machine
  • Thread

parts.notes: in 3 colors: 6–8 white with red from Target, 2–3 brown (I got mine from Hershey), 1 red or whatever color you find attractive with the mix.
You’ll need 26" for the tote, 25" for the hat.

steps.title: Collect and layer your bags, and don’t forget to cover your equipment.

lines.text: Each project will use 4 plastic shopping bags fused into 1 large sheet. To create each project as shown, use 3 Target bags and 1 dark-colored bag, such as a brown Hershey’s bag.
lines.text_raw: Each project will use 4 plastic shopping bags fused into 1 large sheet. To create each project as shown, use 3 Target bags and 1 dark-colored bag, such as a brown Hershey’s bag.

lines.text: With your hands, smooth out one bag at a time onto a work surface. Trim off the handles, cutting across the top of the bag with scissors. Next, trim off 1⁄4" along the bottom of the bag, opening up the pleats. Make 1 straight cut from the top edge of the bag to the bottom to create 1 large, single-layer rectangle. Repeat with the other 3 bags.
lines.text_raw: With your hands, smooth out one bag at a time onto a work surface. Trim off the handles, cutting across the top of the bag with scissors. Next, trim off 1⁄4" along the bottom of the bag, opening up the pleats. Make 1 straight cut from the top edge of the bag to the bottom to create 1 large, single-layer rectangle. Repeat with the other 3 bags.

lines.text: Layer all 4 bags, one on top of another. I placed the brown bag on the bottom and layered the print bags on top, arranging the Target prints to create an all-over pattern.
lines.text_raw: Layer all 4 bags, one on top of another. I placed the brown bag on the bottom and layered the print bags on top, arranging the Target prints to create an all-over pattern.

lines.text: Cover your ironing board with a sheet of parchment paper a few inches longer than your stack of cut plastic bags, about 42" long. Place the layered plastic bags on top, then cover them with another sheet of parchment. The bags will probably be a few inches wider than the parchment, so be sure to keep the plastic completely sandwiched between the paper when you’re fusing it, by repositioning them both as needed.
lines.text_raw: Cover your ironing board with a sheet of parchment paper a few inches longer than your stack of cut plastic bags, about 42" long. Place the layered plastic bags on top, then cover them with another sheet of parchment. The bags will probably be a few inches wider than the parchment, so be sure to keep the plastic completely sandwiched between the paper when you’re fusing it, by repositioning them both as needed.

steps.title: Iron your bags to fuse the materials.

lines.text: Before getting started, be sure your workspace is well ventilated. Some plastics may give off an odor, although I haven’t experienced a problem with this. Set your iron on the synthetics setting. Making sure not to touch the hot iron directly to the plastic, slowly iron on top of the parchment paper. Keep the iron moving. As the plastic layers begin to fuse together, they’ll shrink a bit. Be aware that any ink from the bags will transfer to the paper.
lines.text_raw: Before getting started, be sure your workspace is well ventilated. Some plastics may give off an odor, although I haven’t experienced a problem with this. Set your iron on the synthetics setting. Making sure not to touch the hot iron directly to the plastic, slowly iron on top of the parchment paper. Keep the iron moving. As the plastic layers begin to fuse together, they’ll shrink a bit. Be aware that any ink from the bags will transfer to the paper.

lines.text: I recommend reading through this step and then practicing on a few extra bags first. Experiment with the number of layers and iron temperatures, as this is not an exact science and your results will vary.
lines.text_raw: I recommend reading through this step and then practicing on a few extra bags first. Experiment with the number of layers and iron temperatures, as this is not an exact science and your results will vary.

lines.text: After ironing one area, let it cool before lifting the paper. Check to see if the layers have started to melt together. You may want to increase the iron’s temperature if you find that the plastic isn’t fusing. Reposition the parchment paper and continue this process until you’ve fused the entire length of the stacked layers.
lines.text_raw: After ironing one area, let it cool before lifting the paper. Check to see if the layers have started to melt together. You may want to increase the iron’s temperature if you find that the plastic isn’t fusing. Reposition the parchment paper and continue this process until you’ve fused the entire length of the stacked layers.

lines.text: Turn the fused plastic sheet over, cover with parchment, and repeat the fusing process from the other side. The layers of your fully fused plastic should feel like 1 piece. The trick is to go slowly — an iron that’s too hot will result in fast-shrinking plastic that’s rippled. Once fused, your plastic sheet should measure about 14"×36", big enough to make either the Toadstool Tote or the Rain Bucket Hat.
lines.text_raw: Turn the fused plastic sheet over, cover with parchment, and repeat the fusing process from the other side. The layers of your fully fused plastic should feel like 1 piece. The trick is to go slowly — an iron that’s too hot will result in fast-shrinking plastic that’s rippled. Once fused, your plastic sheet should measure about 14"×36", big enough to make either the Toadstool Tote or the Rain Bucket Hat.

lines.text: To create the tote appliqués as shown, you’ll also need to fuse a small amount of red plastic for the toadstool stems.
lines.text_raw: To create the tote appliqués as shown, you’ll also need to fuse a small amount of red plastic for the toadstool stems.

lines.text: Stitching fused plastic with a machine is fairly easy, as long as the plastic hasn’t become too thick or hard. Use a universal needle and a stitch length of 3–4. Practice stitching on a few scraps and adjust your machine’s tension if necessary to achieve even stitches. Straight pins can be used to hold your work, but if you find that the plastic is too difficult to pin through, try using paper clips.
lines.text_raw: Stitching fused plastic with a machine is fairly easy, as long as the plastic hasn’t become too thick or hard. Use a universal needle and a stitch length of 3–4. Practice stitching on a few scraps and adjust your machine’s tension if necessary to achieve even stitches. Straight pins can be used to hold your work, but if you find that the plastic is too difficult to pin through, try using paper clips.

steps.title: Designing your toadstool tote, make the body of your bag.

lines.text: Appliqués, such as these little toadstools, are quick and fun to do with fused plastic. Plastic shapes fuse easily to this tote, and there are no edges to unravel. Ribbon trim and a little stitching give it a clean, finished look.
lines.text_raw: Appliqués, such as these little toadstools, are quick and fun to do with fused plastic. Plastic shapes fuse easily to this tote, and there are no edges to unravel. Ribbon trim and a little stitching give it a clean, finished look.

lines.text: Using a ruler, mark a rectangle on your fused bags measuring 13"×30". Cut it out with scissors.
lines.text_raw: Using a ruler, mark a rectangle on your fused bags measuring 13"×30". Cut it out with scissors.

lines.text: Place the rectangle, right (brown) side up, onto your work surface. Starting at one of the short ends, fold up a 2" hem toward the right side. Make a crease with your fingers, then pin the hem. Topstitch 1" from the edge. Repeat for the other short end of the rectangle.
lines.text_raw: Place the rectangle, right (brown) side up, onto your work surface. Starting at one of the short ends, fold up a 2" hem toward the right side. Make a crease with your fingers, then pin the hem. Topstitch 1" from the edge. Repeat for the other short end of the rectangle.

lines.text: Using the templates provided online, trace and cut the large and small toadstool tops out of a scrap of Target-print fused plastic and the toadstool stems out of a second color (like the red I used).
lines.text_raw: Using the templates provided online, trace and cut the large and small toadstool tops out of a scrap of Target-print fused plastic and the toadstool stems out of a second color (like the red I used).

lines.text: Place the appliqué shapes onto the right side of the large rectangle, about 4" below the top of the hemmed edge. Cover with parchment paper and fuse into place. Keep the iron moving!
lines.text_raw: Place the appliqué shapes onto the right side of the large rectangle, about 4" below the top of the hemmed edge. Cover with parchment paper and fuse into place. Keep the iron moving!

lines.text: Do not overheat, as this may cause additional shrinkage.
lines.text_raw: Do not overheat, as this may cause additional shrinkage.

lines.text: To add grass below the toadstools, randomly straight-stitch forward and in reverse, pivoting at the top and bottom of the blades of grass.
lines.text_raw: To add grass below the toadstools, randomly straight-stitch forward and in reverse, pivoting at the top and bottom of the blades of grass.

steps.title: Seam the sides and add the box corners.

lines.text: Fold the rectangle, right sides together, matching hemmed edges at the top. Pin the sides and straight-stitch, using a 1⁄4" seam allowance, from top to fold. With a pen, mark the bottom fold near each corner to designate the bottom of the bag.
lines.text_raw: Fold the rectangle, right sides together, matching hemmed edges at the top. Pin the sides and straight-stitch, using a 1⁄4" seam allowance, from top to fold. With a pen, mark the bottom fold near each corner to designate the bottom of the bag.

lines.text: Adding “box corners” gives the bag dimension by adding a seam perpendicular to both the side seam and the bottom fold. With the bag inside out, align one side seam with the mark made on the bottom fold, creating a point at the corner. Measure 2" from the corner, mark a line perpendicular to the side seam, and pin in place. Sew on this line, creating a triangle. Trim the triangle off after stitching. Repeat for the second corner.
lines.text_raw: Adding “box corners” gives the bag dimension by adding a seam perpendicular to both the side seam and the bottom fold. With the bag inside out, align one side seam with the mark made on the bottom fold, creating a point at the corner. Measure 2" from the corner, mark a line perpendicular to the side seam, and pin in place. Sew on this line, creating a triangle. Trim the triangle off after stitching. Repeat for the second corner.

lines.text: Turn the bag right side out. Place your ribbon along the edge of the opening’s hem, covering the stitch line, and pin. Topstitch 1 edge of the ribbon all the way around the bag. Repeat for the other edge.
lines.text_raw: Turn the bag right side out. Place your ribbon along the edge of the opening’s hem, covering the stitch line, and pin. Topstitch 1 edge of the ribbon all the way around the bag. Repeat for the other edge.

lines.text: Cut 2 straps, measuring 2"×13" each, from the remaining scraps. Fold 1 strap in thirds, lengthwise. Pin and topstitch the length of the strap 1" from each edge. Repeat for the second strap.
lines.text_raw: Cut 2 straps, measuring 2"×13" each, from the remaining scraps. Fold 1 strap in thirds, lengthwise. Pin and topstitch the length of the strap 1" from each edge. Repeat for the second strap.

lines.text: Measure and mark your strap placement on the front of your bag, 3" in from each side seam. Pin each end of 1 strap to these marks, overlapping the inside edge of the bag 1⁄2". Repeat for the second strap on the back of the bag, taking care not to twist the straps.
lines.text_raw: Measure and mark your strap placement on the front of your bag, 3" in from each side seam. Pin each end of 1 strap to these marks, overlapping the inside edge of the bag 1⁄2". Repeat for the second strap on the back of the bag, taking care not to twist the straps.

lines.text: Topstitch the top edge of the bag, stitching through each strap end to secure it. For extra reinforcement, stitch across the strap ends a second time. You’re done!
lines.text_raw: Topstitch the top edge of the bag, stitching through each strap end to secure it. For extra reinforcement, stitch across the strap ends a second time. You’re done!

steps.title: Cut out pattern pieces for your rain bucket hat.

lines.text: Back in the day of beauty parlor hairdos, ladies would keep plastic rain hats (or worse, a plastic bag!) in their pocketbooks should they encounter an unexpected downpour. Now you can keep your ’do dry and stylish with plastic bags — fused and stitched into this sassy Rain Bucket Hat!
lines.text_raw: Back in the day of beauty parlor hairdos, ladies would keep plastic rain hats (or worse, a plastic bag!) in their pocketbooks should they encounter an unexpected downpour. Now you can keep your ’do dry and stylish with plastic bags — fused and stitched into this sassy Rain Bucket Hat!

lines.text: Using the pattern online, cut out 1 hat top, 2 hat sides (each cut on a fold), and 2 brims (each cut on a fold), from a large sheet of fused plastic.
lines.text_raw: Using the pattern online, cut out 1 hat top, 2 hat sides (each cut on a fold), and 2 brims (each cut on a fold), from a large sheet of fused plastic.

lines.text: Place the 2 hat sides right sides together, and seam the ends using a 1⁄4" seam allowance. Press open the seam allowances with your fingers, and topstitch them open on either side of the seam line. Repeat for the second seam.
lines.text_raw: Place the 2 hat sides right sides together, and seam the ends using a 1⁄4" seam allowance. Press open the seam allowances with your fingers, and topstitch them open on either side of the seam line. Repeat for the second seam.

steps.title: Join the top to the sides.

lines.text: Fold the hat top in half and mark the halfway points with pins. With right sides together, align these pins with the side seams of the sewn hat sides, along the top edge. Distribute the material evenly, pinning the top edge of the hat sides to the hat top. Stitch using a 1⁄4" seam allowance.
lines.text_raw: Fold the hat top in half and mark the halfway points with pins. With right sides together, align these pins with the side seams of the sewn hat sides, along the top edge. Distribute the material evenly, pinning the top edge of the hat sides to the hat top. Stitch using a 1⁄4" seam allowance.

steps.title: Sew the brim, then join the brim to the sides.

lines.text: Place the 2 brim pieces right sides together, and sew the ends using a 1⁄4" seam allowance. Finger-press open the seam allowances and topstitch them open on either side of the seam line. Repeat for the second seam.
lines.text_raw: Place the 2 brim pieces right sides together, and sew the ends using a 1⁄4" seam allowance. Finger-press open the seam allowances and topstitch them open on either side of the seam line. Repeat for the second seam.

lines.text: Fold a 1⁄4" hem around the perimeter of the brim. Pin and topstitch 1" from the fold.
lines.text_raw: Fold a 1⁄4" hem around the perimeter of the brim. Pin and topstitch 1" from the fold.

lines.text: With right sides together, align the side seams of the hat sides with the seams of the brim. Distribute the material evenly, pinning the bottom edge of the hat sides to the inside curve of the brim. Stitch using a 1⁄4" seam allowance.
lines.text_raw: With right sides together, align the side seams of the hat sides with the seams of the brim. Distribute the material evenly, pinning the bottom edge of the hat sides to the inside curve of the brim. Stitch using a 1⁄4" seam allowance.

lines.text: Flip the brim down and finger-press the seam allowances up toward the inside of the hat. Edge-stitch the seam allowances to the hat sides, 1" from the seam.
lines.text_raw: Flip the brim down and finger-press the seam allowances up toward the inside of the hat. Edge-stitch the seam allowances to the hat sides, 1" from the seam.

lines.text: Apply waterproof glue around the seam where the hat sides meet the brim and press a length of ribbon (about 25") into place to create a hatband. Allow the glue to dry.
lines.text_raw: Apply waterproof glue around the seam where the hat sides meet the brim and press a length of ribbon (about 25") into place to create a hatband. Allow the glue to dry.

guide.summary: Fuse your plastic shopping bags into fun, retro-modern accessories.
guide.title: Toadstool Tote and Rain Bucket Hat
